content: it's orc tober i'm gonna try my hand at orc terrain for the first time
in the immortal words of big boss giga gob
quote
hello everyone weilock here thanks for joining me and today i am in trouble
for i cannot rely upon my speed square
yeah one of my top five favorite tools
but highly unorc-like so cannot use it mike from scratch bashing
frankie d crafter and several other youtubers do
orctober just an orc project bringing awareness
to the plight of the orc there's a bunch of links in the video
description below to their videos and remember that our sponsor is heroes
horde for you 3d printers out there excellent selection including all true
tiles lines i checked the size of my battle wagon to
make sure that it would fit beneath the archway
i know i want this piece to be like a readout like a fortress wall
and that there should be a way for vehicles to get in and out
so i kind of just blocked it out a little bit and then went about cutting
up some double corrugated cardboard not worrying about angles here which was
kind of refreshing and again i want to make sure that the
battle wagon can fit it's the biggest vehicle that that i have at least
all these pieces are attached together with hot glue that double corrugation
provides a lot of area for the glue to seep into and make
a very strong bond also by holding it in place at an odd
angle you can help ensure that the walls aren't parallel and that they're also
not perpendicular to the ground because i want that skewed look
as much as i possibly can there that's a horribly
non-rectangular rectangle corners don't meet
edges don't agree that's the goal i even have some of these floors that are
sloping not enough that a miniature will move but
sloping and boy can you move fast when you don't have to measure when you're
working this way i'm using the ruler but it's just to be
able to cut straight edges because straight edges are important
we don't want a lot if any curves in this piece
there you go top down view there's not a single
parallel or perpendicular thing to be found
same with from any view that's what that was my goal and i feel like i
accomplished it so this is my skeleton this is the thing
that's ready to be decorated up and made more orky my go-to is gonna be
as always graphics medium chipboard this is the
stuff you find at the back of a legal pad but you can buy it in bulk like i do
there's links in the video description below
cutting up some strips and eventually i know that these are gonna be
metal panels right they're scavenged metal panels that's what orcs do
trying to cut no regular rectangles they always have
some weird skew to them don't be afraid to use google image search that's what i
did just search orc terrain work with a k so you get 40k results but
uh you get ideas like this the teeth and a sense for the size and overlaps to aim
for corrugated cardboard okay this is a
timeless classic right everyone's used this for decades you
peel the paper off one side and now you've got nice corrugated metal
texture attaching that with hot glue never
straight okay a little bit crooked and that really helps sell the look it
helps it give that distinctive fork aesthetic i wanted a couple patches
of ground this was actually an excuse to create a
post and reinforce that balcony you see but with the ground there i'll have a
place to stack up munitions or boxes or skulls or
something i'm not sure yet what but it's just a place that i can put some more
stuff make it a little more interesting tell a little more of a story
and here i'm trying to replicate an official orc bit
this is from a vehicle but you know look at the official bits get inspiration and
try to replicate them with cardboard or chipboard
now i kept telling myself keep going keep going there's not enough on there
you're gonna regret if you don't add enough detail excess detail is a great
way to get away with a simple paint job which i definitely intend on doing
here i'm building the banner holder i guess you'd call it whatever
this post is going to go up and it helps attach that floor piece so it creates
two axes of rigidity there and now i'm making another one of those
i-beams from the extractor video that's mounted on the other side here's
a couple of plastic bits left over from an ebay rescue
just sort of thinking how they're gonna go together and they're going to be the
mounting point for that classic big orc skull so i'm
going to cut that out of chipboard like you see here
that's the lower jaw and here's the upper skull and voila
there it is cutting the eyes out and i'm going to mount this
on just a bit of plastic and then attach that to the gantry
this is much stronger than it looks because all connection points have two
axes of control this also introduced a second connection
point for the overall piece with that bridge so it doesn't flex anymore
how about a plastic fork i broke off the tines just experimenting with them
glued a few of them on they look okay it's kind of orky but
i'm not going to use them anymore i'm going to use chipboard to make spikes
but i'll leave those there as a non-repeating
single point of interest a ladder i found some ladders in my bits
but i want to make some too an orky ladder
would be slipshod crooked just like this so it's just
wooden dowels and some bits of matchstick i made a few
of those and placed them logically so that anywhere on the structure could
actually be accessed this is the metal grille of a cheap
speaker it's thin it's very sturdy but it is
metal i tried to cut it and with all my effort
yes it does just barely cut it blunted my scissors but it it did cut
it so i'm gonna use this to make a bridge
between two sections this is a leftover bit of sprue
and with some super glue and some super glue accelerant
i could quickly put it on the edge and this helped to reinforce the rigidity
now it's not going to bend also those left over nubs
on the sprue are mounting points for future
guns or panels or whatever else i want to attach i hadn't thought that far
ahead this is granny grading a cross stitching
mesh available at the sewing aisle of any
crafting store or big box store this along with chipboard will be a
bunch of panels for all of the flooring so here it is done this took about two
hours to get to this point and i was pretty happy with how it
turned out i thought i didn't know i was capable of
producing something this chaotic so it was pretty pretty cool feeling
i'll turn it around we'll get a look at the other side here
there's a mixture of leftover plastic bits
and chipboard right most of it is scratch built in its chipboard but i do
occasionally mix in some of those bits the finer detail in those is gonna help
to sell it chipboard is also fibrous so it takes
paint very well and it can be dry brushed it's
got a naturally slightly fuzzy texture to it so once you
put down your base coat you can go back and lightly dry brush it
you get instant texture for free unlike say styrene card or
something like that so yeah looking good it's very durable
feels great it's heavy uh the next thing to do is
take it outside and prime it i don't have any black primer left but i
know i want this to have a reddish look overall
so i'll use this now this is a large piece
and i know i'm going to make more scatter in the future that needs to
match it aesthetically so whatever i do for a paint job
needs to be simple fast and reproducible it's like i primed it with black anyway
the first thing to do is an over brush with gunmetal
this is a dark silverish metallic and i use this new mop brush
to make the job quick this is a heavier touch than a dry brush but it's not a
base coat something like 85 should be covered the
little bit of black and the crevices where the brush can't reach
automatically creates natural shadows then i went to a natural red and again
with the mop just going over the whole piece and making those
panels red because orcs love red then with a lighter metallic silver
color i restored the corrugation and some of the other features to
non-red straight metal to differentiate them make them pop out to the eye a
little more and then in the wee hours of the morning
before work i got out my homemade wash courtesy of midwinter minis for the
recipe same wash i've used in recent videos and
slathered it over the entire thing got home from work and it
was all dry nicely yuckied up so i took a shimmering silver and i'm
gonna lightly dry brush i'm not in the mood to edge highlight so
i'll just try and use a light touch and catch all the edges
but that failed something about this just didn't look right it kind of looks
like i don't know red leather texture or i
don't maybe it's too uniform maybe the floor shouldn't be red
so i went back in and restored some of the floor panels to gunmetal
that helped a little and now it needs
some orangification some more textures so i've got my valeo
environmental effects paints that i've fallen back on in the past
love these so i'm just going to mess around with them slathering on good
amounts of diesel fuel stains and the rust texture
that i've harped on in the past rust texture is so good at making you
look better than you really are love that stuff
but already i see it's making a huge difference it's toning down some of that
red it's introducing some complexity making it look a little more realistic
and i think this is gonna do the trick unfortunately i have to wait several
hours for it to dry but i think i'm more on the right track
now still not quite there i'm gonna go back
in and do some minor details gotta have white checkers white checker
patterns is orc so i'm gonna hand paint a few of those on
also this door underneath i'm gonna paint a grayish color
and i think the big skull emblem up top i'm going to paint that with a very
light gray as well and i'll throw some washes on there
maybe an orangey brown on the rungs of this ladder
just to make it different an off-white on these tusks
and now let's get a look at it well this was certainly something new for me but
boy was it liberating no measuring just slap dash move move
move i built the thing in like two hours and
i painted it in another two really fun and with the orc aesthetic you really
can't go wrong i actually find myself excited to make
some more matching scatter terrain six or seven large pieces like this and
i've got a table again visit the other youtubers who
celebrate or october their videos are linked in the description
below and i thank them for bringing me into the fold this year
i don't have a whole lot more to say because i'm still kind of new to the
orc culture as it were so i'm just gonna move the camera around here and shut up
for a minute
rockin and in the near future i am gonna
try and get a video put out with all my orc army on
parade if you're not already make sure to join
us on facebook at the tabletop crafters guild
35 000 members strong and growing join up post your orc creations
celebrate orctober i'm weilock see you next time make things and play games
you
